questions.text: Corneal endothelium receives most of its oxygen supply from:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aqueous Humour

 

Option C:
 

  • Endothelium receives its maximum oxygen supply from the aqueous humour.
  • Has an oxygen tension of about 40 mm of Hg.
  • The cornea derives its nourishment from three sources:
    1. Oxygen directly from the air
    2. Solutes from the perilimbal capillaries
    3. The aqueous humour.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The tear film primarily supplies oxygen to the corneal epithelium (the outermost layer of the cornea), not the endothelium (the innermost layer).

 

Option B. Atmospheric air is a major source of oxygen for the corneal epithelium when the eye is open. However, the corneal endothelium does not directly access oxygen from the air.

 

Option D. The vitreous humour is the gel-like substance filling the space between the lens and the retina. It does not play a significant role in supplying oxygen to the corneal endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium, being an avascular layer, primarily receives its oxygen supply from the aqueous humour, which nourishes the inner layers of the cornea.

 

Ref: pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following pump system(s) is/are present on the corneal endothelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pump systems present on the corneal endothelium are:

 

 

  1. Na- K ATPase
  2. Na- H
  3. Bicarbonate dependent ATPase
  4. Carbonic Anhydrase Enzyme

 

 

Ref: pg 45/ / Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The minimum oxygen tension for normal corneal dehydration ranges between?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 11 to 19 mm of Hg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimal O2 tension for normal corneal dehydration ranges between 11 to 19 mm of Hg.

 

Below this critical range, the cornea will hydrate and swell.

 

 

Ref:  pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The most actively metabolising layers of cornea are?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epithelium & Endothelium

 

Option D: Epithelium & endothelium are the most actively metabolising layers of cornea.

 

Epithelium is 10x thicker than the latter, and requires a proportionately larger supply of metabolic substrates.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epithelium & Bowman’s Layer: The epithelium is a highly active metabolic layer. However, Bowman's layer, which lies beneath the epithelium, is an acellular zone and does not engage in active metabolism.

 

Option B. Epithelium & Stroma: The stroma is the thickest layer of the cornea and contains collagen and keratocytes. While it has some metabolic activity, it is not as metabolically active as the epithelium or endothelium.

 

Option C. Epithelium & Descemet’s Membrane: Descemet's membrane is a thin, acellular layer produced by the endothelial cells. It does not have significant metabolic activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epithelium and endothelium are the most actively metabolizing layers of the cornea, playing vital roles in corneal health, repair, and functionality.

 

 

Ref: pg 40/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: Also called as Lattice Theory
Scattered light is destroyed by mutual interference
Loss of transparency results if lattice arrangement is altered.

questions.text: Which of the following is/are true about MAURICE theory?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Educational Objective:

 

MAURICE or LATTICE THEORY

 

 

  • Arrangement is altered by stromal edema & mechanical stress
  • If the distance between collagen fibrils increases, it leads to bullae formation.
  • Corneal transparency is maintained by
    • Dehydrated state (hydration leads to loss of transparency)
    • Avascularity
    • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae
    • Unmyleinated nerve fibres

 

 

Ref: pg 42/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The normal corneal stromal swelling pressure is __ mm of Hg:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60

 

Option C:

 

  • Swelling pressure is the keystone of cornea biophysics.
  • Normal = 55 - 60 mm of Hg
  • The cornea is 78% water. This balance of water is maintained by swelling pressure, intraocular pressure (draw water in) and Na+/K+ pumps of endothelium, mechanical barrier of epithelium and endothelium (push water out).

 

 

Ref: pg 44/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

2. https://iovs.arvojournals.org/article.aspx?articleid=2159017

choices.text: Corneal epithelium being hydrophilic is crossed readily by polar drugs.
Fluorescein cannot penetrate intact epithelium which forms the basis of dye test.
Dipivefrin is a pro drug which is converted into epinephrine after absorption into the eye.
Contact lenses reduce the availability of oxygen to epithelium.

questions.text: Identify the false statement among the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corneal epithelium being hydrophilic is crossed readily by polar drugs.

 

Option A:

 

  • Corneal epithelium & endothelium are LIPOPHILIC.
  • Crossed readily by NON-POLAR/ LIPID SOLUBLE drugs.
  • Due to its lipophilic nature, it is not readily crossed by polar (hydrophilic) drugs. Lipophilic drugs, on the other hand, pass more easily through the corneal epithelium.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Fluorescein and Intact Epithelium: Fluorescein cannot penetrate an intact corneal epithelium. The dye test with fluorescein is used to detect epithelial defects; the dye will only penetrate where there are disruptions in the epithelium.

 

Option C. Dipivefrin as a Prodrug: Dipivefrin is a prodrug of epinephrine. It is designed to be more lipophilic, allowing better penetration through the cornea. Once inside the eye, it is converted to epinephrine.

 

Option D. Contact Lenses and Oxygen Availability: Contact lenses, especially those that are not gas-permeable, can reduce the amount of oxygen that reaches the corneal epithelium. This can lead to complications such as corneal hypoxia, especially with prolonged wear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal epithelium's lipophilic nature means that it is not readily crossed by polar drugs. Understanding the epithelium's characteristics is important for effective ocular drug delivery.

 

 

Ref: pg 46/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

questions.text: The corneal stromal lamellae consist of fibrils made of collagen except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 4

 

Educational Objective:

 

collagen type 4 is present predominantly in the descemetâ€™s membrane, not in the stroma

 

 

 

Ref: pg 34/ anatomy and physiology of eye/ AK KHURANA/ 3rd edition

choices.text: Reduced availability of oxygen to the epithelium
Shift of aerobic metabolism to anaerobic
Inhibition of aerobic enzymes such as hexokinase

questions.text: The effects of contact lens on cornea include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactate levels decrease.

 

Option C: Lactate levels increase due to anaerobic metabolism.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reduced Availability of Oxygen to the Epithelium: Contact lenses, especially those that are not gas-permeable, can reduce the oxygen supply to the corneal epithelium, leading to hypoxic conditions.

 

Option B. Shift of Aerobic Metabolism to Anaerobic: When the oxygen supply to the cornea is reduced due to contact lens wear, the corneal cells may shift from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism to meet their energy needs.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Aerobic Enzymes Such as Hexokinase: Prolonged hypoxic conditions caused by contact lens wear can lead to inhibition of enzymes involved in aerobic metabolism. Hexokinase is an enzyme involved early in the glycolysis pathway, and its activity can be affected by changes in the cellular environment due to contact lens use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contact lens wear can lead to reduced oxygen availability to the cornea, a shift from aerobic to anaerobic metabolism, and an increase in lactate levels, not a decrease.

questions.text: Protein synthesis is maximum in which layer of cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelium

 

Option A: Protein synthesis in epithelium

                    - 5X that of stroma

                    - 2X that of Descemet’s membrane & endothelium

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stroma: While the stroma is the thickest layer of the cornea and contains collagen and keratocytes, its rate of protein synthesis is less compared to the epithelium. The stromal cells are relatively quiescent under normal conditions.

 

Option C. Descemet’s Membrane: Descemet's membrane is a specialized basement membrane produced by the endothelial cells. While it does involve protein synthesis, particularly during its formation and repair, it is not the site of maximum protein synthesis in the cornea.

 

Option D. Endothelium: The endothelium is a single layer of cells on the inner surface of the cornea. These cells are metabolically active and involved in maintaining corneal hydration and transparency, but their rate of protein synthesis is not as high as that of the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal epithelium is the site of maximum protein synthesis in the cornea, reflecting its role in continual cell renewal and maintenance of corneal integrity.

 

 

Ref: pg 37/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Major net weight is contributed by which biochemical component in the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Water

 

Option C: Biochemical components of cornea:

  1. Water – 70 to 80%
  2. Solids - 20 to 30 %
  • GAGs
  • Proteins
  • Collagen
  • Salts

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Proteins are a crucial component of the cornea, particularly in the form of collagen in the stroma, but they do not constitute the majority of the cornea's weight.

 

Option B. Mucopolysaccharides, or glycosaminoglycans, are important for the structure and function of the cornea, especially in maintaining its transparency and hydration. However, they do not make up the majority of the cornea's weight.

 

Option D. While lipids are present in the cornea, they are not a major component in terms of weight. The cornea is relatively avascular and does not have a significant lipid content compared to other tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cornea's major net weight is contributed by water, which is essential for maintaining its transparency, thickness, and overall function.

 

 

Ref: pg 38 / Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The major glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) fractions found in cornea are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heparan Sulphate

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornea contains 3 major glycosaminoglycan fractions:

  • Keratan Sulphate (50%)
  • Dermatan Sulphate (25%)
  • Chondroitin (25%)

 

 

Ref:  pg. 39 / Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

2. AAO/ 2020–2021 BCSC Basic and Clinical Science Course / 2 Fundamentals and Principles of Ophthalmology/Part IV: Biochemistry and Metabolism/Chapter 8: Cornea

questions.text: Metabolic pathways in cornea include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluconeogenesis

 

Option B: This is the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources.

 

Unlike other tissues like the liver, the cornea does not significantly engage in gluconeogenesis. The cornea primarily relies on glucose from the aqueous humor and utilizes it through glycolysis.

 

Metabolic pathways for ATP production in cornea are:

  • Glycolysis
  • Citric Acid/ Kerb’s Cycle
  • HMP Pathway

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glycolysis is a fundamental metabolic pathway that occurs in the cornea. It involves the breakdown of glucose to produce energy, and it is especially crucial in the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Krebs Cycle, also known as the citric acid cycle, this is a key metabolic pathway that takes place in the mitochondria. The cornea, particularly the endothelium and epithelium, uses the Krebs cycle for energy production.

 

Option D. Hexose Monophosphate Pathway, also known as the pentose phosphate pathway, is present in the cornea. It's important for generating NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate, essential for biosynthetic reactions and maintaining redox balance in cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the cornea, metabolic pathways like glycolysis, the Krebs cycle, and the hexose monophosphate pathway are active, but gluconeogenesis is not a significant metabolic process in the cornea.

 

 

Ref: pg 41/ Anatomy & Physiology of Eye /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Ananya, a 22-year-old female who has myopia visits the ophthalmologist and requests her to eliminate the need to wear spectacles in order to see clearly. The ophthalmologist examines her thoroughly, suggests her a surgery involving the cornea which can solve her problem. Of the outer fibrous coat of the eyeball, what fraction is contributed by the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1/6th

 

Option C: The outer fibrous coat of the eyeball consists of:

  • Anterior 1/6th    = Cornea
  • Posterior 5/6th = Sclera

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornea contributes the anterior 1/6th of the outer coat of the eye.

 

 

 

Ref: pg 2/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: In 2013, the Dua’s layer of the cornea was discovered by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Harminder Singh

 

Option C: Pre-Descemet’s membrane, also known as Dua’s layer was discovered in 2013 by Dr. Harminder Dua, Indian origin ophthalmologist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Layers of the cornea outermost to innermost:

  • Epithelium: Grips the tear film with help of microvilli.
  • Bowman’s membrane: Not a true basement membrane (PAS negative).
  • Stroma: Thickest layer. Contains Collagen 1,3,5+ GAGs (Keratan Sulphate).
  • Dua’s layer: Strongest layer.
  • Descemet’s membrane
  • Endothelium: Most metabolically active. Max Na+/K+ pumps.

 

 

Ref: pg 35/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbus

 

Option B:

  • Limbus refers to a circumcorneal transitional zone of the conjunctivocorneal & corneoscleral junction.
  • It has basal cells arranged in folds, increasing surface area for the mitotically active stem cells. This is called as PALLISADES OF VOGT.
  • Contains unipotent stem cells.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The retina is the light-sensitive layer that processes visual information.

 

Option C. Aqueous Humour is the clear fluid in the anterior chamber of the eye, between the cornea and the lens.

 

Option D. Cornea, while the Palisades of Vogt are closely related to the health and maintenance of the cornea, they are specifically located in the limbus, not within the cornea itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Palisades of Vogt, containing stem cells crucial for corneal regeneration and repair, are located in the limbus, the border area between the cornea and the sclera.

 

 

Ref: pg 50/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Each medium through which light rays travel to reach the retina has a distinct refractive power. The refractive power of the cornea is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) + 43 D

 

Explanation:

  • The refractive power of anterior surface of the cornea is +48 D.
  • Posterior surface of the cornea is - 5D.
  • Net refractive power of the cornea =   + 43 D
  • 3/4TH the total refractive power of the eye.
  • The rest 1/4th is contributed by Lens (+20D).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The net refractive power of cornea is +43 D.

 

 

Ref: pg 32/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A patient is being worked-up to be posted for LASIK surgery is undergoing Pachymetry, to check for the corneal thickness. Which layer of the cornea will have maximum thickness?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stroma

 

Option B:

  • Stroma is the thickest layer of the cornea. (90%)
  • It consists of collagen 1, 3, 5 embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans (Keratan Sulphate).
  • In a healthy eye, the stroma is approximately 500 micrometers thick. It provides the cornea with its strength, elasticity, and form.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epithelium: The corneal epithelium is the outermost layer of the cornea and is relatively thin, typically about 50-60 micrometers in thickness. It serves as a barrier against dust, debris, and microorganisms.

 

Option C. Descemet's membrane is a thin layer of tissue that serves as the basement membrane of the corneal endothelium. Its thickness is much less compared to the stroma, only about 5-10 micrometers.

 

Option D. The endothelium is the innermost layer of the cornea and is also quite thin, typically 5 micrometers or less in thickness. It is responsible for maintaining corneal dehydration and transparency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stromal layer is the thickest part of the cornea, making up about 90% of its total thickness, and is crucial for the cornea's tensile strength and form.

 

 

Ref:  pg 96/ CORNEA/ Comprehensive ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

questions.text: The corneal reflex is a demonstration performed by gently touching the cornea with a sterile cotton swab. This causes a protective reflex where the patient's eye immediately closes involuntarily. It helps in assessing the integrity of the sensory and motor pathways involved in eye protection. Which of the following is the afferent for this reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Long Ciliary Nerve.

 

The afferent pathway would be as follows - 
long ciliary nerve â€“ ciliary ganglion â€“ nasociliary nerve â€“ ophthalmic nerve â€”trigeminal nerve â€“ trigeminal ganglion â€“ trigeminal nucleus

 

Option D: The nasociliary branch enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure within the annulus of Zinn, entering the intraconal space and traveling anteriorly to innervate the eye via the ciliary branches.

 

The short ciliary nerves penetrate the sclera after passing through the ciliary ganglion without synapse.

 

The long ciliary nerves pass by the ciliary ganglion and enter the sclera, where they extend anteriorly to supply the iris, cornea, and ciliary muscle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve: This is a motor nerve involved in controlling most of the eye's movements and is not the afferent limb of the corneal reflex.

 

Option B. Short Ciliary Nerve: They supply parasympathetic and sympathetic nerve fibers to the ciliary muscle, iris, and cornea.

 

Option C. Optic Nerve transmits visual information from the retina to the brain and is not involved in the sensory pathway of the corneal reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the corneal reflex, the long ciliary nerves serve as the afferent limb, responsible for transmitting sensory information from the cornea to the brain upon stimulation.

 

 

Ref:

  1. AAO/2020â€“2021 BCSC Basic and Clinical Science Course/ 7 Oculofacial Plastic and Orbital Surgery/Part I: Orbit/Chapter 1: Orbital Anatomy
  2. Yang AY, Chow J, Liu J. Corneal Innervation and Sensation: The Eye and Beyond. Yale J Biol Med. 2018 Mar 28;91(1):13-21. PMID: 29599653; PMCID: PMC5872636.

choices.text: Duration of contact of drug with epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following factors does not contribute to the control of drug penetration through the corneal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Water solubility

 

Option B: The epithelium is more permeable to fat soluble substances and stroma to water soluble substances.

 

The passage of drugs through the epithelium is determined by following factors:

  • Fat solubility
  • Molecular weight below 500
  • The degree of dissociation of the electrolytes
  • Duration of contact of the drug with the corneal epithelium

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Duration of Contact of Drug with Epithelium: The longer a drug remains in contact with the corneal epithelium, the greater the opportunity for absorption. Factors such as formulation and viscosity of the drug can affect this contact time.

 

Option C. Molecular Weight <500: The molecular weight of a drug can influence its ability to penetrate biological membranes.

 

Option D. Degree of Dissociation of Electrolytes: The corneal epithelium is more permeable to non-ionized (non-dissociated) drug forms. The degree of ionization (dissociation) affects drug penetration, as ionized molecules typically penetrate less effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal epithelium is lipophilic; therefore, drugs that are too hydrophilic (water-soluble) may have difficulty penetrating it. Optimal penetration often requires a balance between lipophilic and hydrophilic properties.

 

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 146

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not recommended for topical use?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetylcholine

 

Option D: Acetylcholine doesn’t penetrate the corneal epithelium well and it is rapidly degraded by Ach esterase. Thus, it is not used topically.

 

Ach 1% is available for intracameral use in anterior segment surgery to produce prompt miosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pilocarpine is commonly used as a topical medication in ophthalmology. It is a cholinergic agonist that reduces intraocular pressure in glaucoma and can also be used for inducing miosis during eye surgeries.

 

Option B. Apraclonidine is used as a topical eye drop. It's an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that works by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure, particularly in the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option C. Phenylephrine is used topically in ophthalmology as a mydriatic agent; it dilates the pupils without affecting accommodation. It's used for diagnostic procedures and in preoperative preparations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ophthalmology, acetylcholine is not recommended for topical use due to its rapid hydrolysis and short half-life, while pilocarpine, apraclonidine, and phenylephrine are commonly used as topical eye medications.

 

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 419

questions.text: What is the concentration of pilocarpine used in diagnosis of Adie’s tonic pupil?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.125%

 

Option C: Adie’s tonic pupil is a condition wherein parasympathetic innervation of iris sphincter and ciliary muscle is defective due to loss of post ganglionic fibers.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 0.5% Pilocarpine is a higher concentration of pilocarpine. In a normal eye, 0.5% pilocarpine will cause some constriction of the pupil due to its cholinergic effect on the sphincter pupillae muscle. However, this concentration is too high for the specific testing of Adie's tonic pupil, as it can induce constriction in both normal and affected pupils.

 

Option B. 0.25% Pilocarpine: Similar to 0.5%, this concentration is also relatively high for the purpose of diagnosing Adie's tonic pupil. While it might not be as potent as 0.5%, it can still cause constriction in normal pupils, thus not as effective for differentiating Adie's tonic pupil.

 

Option D. 1% Pilocarpine: This is a higher concentration and would typically be used in other clinical situations, not for Adie’s tonic pupil. At this concentration, pilocarpine will induce constriction in almost any pupil, regardless of its normality or pathology, due to its strong cholinergic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When diagnosing Adie's tonic pupil, 0.125% pilocarpine is used, as affected pupils will constrict to this low concentration due to denervation hypersensitivity, unlike normal pupils which show no response.

 

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 420

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones is known to cause white, crystalline corneal deposits?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ciprofloxacin

 

Option C: Ocular side effects of fluoroquinolones:

  • Transient ocular burning or discomfort – most frequent
  • Stinging, Redness, Itching
  • Chemical Conjunctivitis/Keratitis
  • Periocular/Facial Edema
  • Foreign-Body Sensation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both norfloxacin and ciprofloxacin cause white, crystalline corneal deposits of medication, which resolve after discontinuation of the drug

 

 

Ref: AAO SECTION: 2 – 2020 EDITION PAGE 423

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea does not regenerate once it is destroyed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowmans

 

Option B:

  • Bowman’s membrane lies under the epithelium.
  • It is a condensed superficial part of stroma.
  • Made of type 1 & 5 collagen
  • Once destroyed it does not regenerate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epithelium: The corneal epithelium can regenerate. If damaged, the surrounding epithelial cells will migrate, proliferate, and remodel to repair the defect.

 

Option C. Descemet's Membrane: Descemet's membrane can regenerate to some extent, especially in younger individuals. Endothelial cells adjacent to an area of damage can enlarge and migrate to cover small defects.

 

Option D. Endothelium: The corneal endothelium has limited regenerative capacity. While endothelial cells can enlarge and migrate to cover small gaps, they do not proliferate. Significant damage to the endothelium can lead to corneal edema and vision impairment, as these cells are crucial for maintaining corneal deturgescence and transparency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of corneal anatomy, it's important to recognize that Bowman's layer does not regenerate once destroyed, distinguishing it from other corneal layers like the epithelium, Descemet's membrane, and endothelium, which have some capacity for repair or regeneration.

 

 

Ref: pg 34/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is the corneal endothelial cell count at birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6000.

 

Option D: The cell density of the corneal endothelium is:

  • At birth = 6000 cells/ mm2
  • Adults   = 2500- 3000 cells/mm2

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelial cell count at birth is 6000 cells/mm2.

 

 

 

Ref: pg 36/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which of the following structure has no blood supply?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cornea

 

Option A:

  • Cornea is avascular

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Sclera, although less richly supplied than other parts of the eye, it has blood vessels that provide necessary nutrients and remove waste.

 

Option C. The retina is highly vascularized and requires a rich blood supply to support its complex and high-energy functions, including photoreception and initial visual processing.

 

Option D. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye containing connective tissue and lying between the retina and the sclera. It is heavily vascularized and provides oxygen and nutrients to the outer layers of the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cornea is the only structure among the given options that has no blood supply, relying instead on the aqueous humor and tear film for nutrients and oxygen, which is crucial for its transparency and vision function.

 

 

Ref: pg 36/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: What is the refractive index of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1.376

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The refractive index of cornea is 1.376.

 

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology Khurana Page26

questions.text: This stain helps in identification of which of the following defect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Degenerated Cells

 

Option C:

  • The given picture shows staining with Rose Bengal 1% dye.
  • It stains diseased and devitalized cells, red.
  • It is very irritative to ocular surface hence topical xylocaine is used prior to staining with rose Bengal dye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Epithelial Defect: While rose bengal can stain damaged or devitalized epithelial cells, it's not the primary choice for detecting epithelial defects. Fluorescein stain is more commonly used for this purpose because it highlights defects more clearly by fluorescing under a blue light.

 

Option B. Aqueous Leak: Rose bengal is not used for detecting aqueous leaks. Fluorescein dye is typically used for this purpose in a test known as the Seidel test, which can detect leaks from the anterior chamber of the eye.

 

Option D. Descemet’s Detachment: Descemet's membrane detachment is a condition where the innermost layer of the cornea separates from the rest of the corneal layers. Rose bengal is not specifically used for detecting Descemet's detachment. Other diagnostic tools, like slit-lamp examination and anterior segment OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography), are more suitable for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rose bengal stain is primarily used to identify degenerated or damaged epithelial cells, mucous filaments, and other devitalized cells, making it a valuable tool in diagnosing conditions like dry eye syndrome.

 

 

Ref: KHURANA COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY 5th ed. PAGE 502

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from neural ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Descemet’s membrane

 

Option D: Structures derived from neuroectoderm:

 

  • Retina
  • Retinal pigment epithelium
  • Optic nerve fibres
  • Sphincter & dilator pupillae
  • Iris epithelium
  • Secondary vitreous

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Melanocytes are derived from the neural crest, which itself is a component of the neural ectoderm. During development, cells from the neural crest migrate to various parts of the body, including the skin, where they differentiate into melanocytes.

 

Option B. The optic nerve, which transmits visual information from the retina to the brain, is a part of the central nervous system (CNS). It is derived from the neural ectoderm. During embryonic development, the optic nerve forms from the outgrowth of the diencephalon, a part of the brain which is itself an extension of the neural ectoderm.

 

Option C. The retina is derived from the neural ectoderm. It develops from the optic vesicles, which are outgrowths of the diencephalon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Descemet’s Membrane is the basement membrane that lies between the corneal stroma and the endothelial layer of the cornea. Unlike the other options, Descemet's membrane is not derived from the neural ectoderm. Instead, it originates from mesodermal tissue. The mesoderm is a different germ layer from the ectoderm and gives rise to structures like muscle, bone, and connective tissues, including components of the eye like Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Ref: pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6th edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Associated with connective tissue disorder in 50% cases
Pain is not a prominent feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding Scleritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with connective tissue disorder in 50% cases

 

Option B: It is associated with connective tissue disease in 50% of cases and hence a thorough investigation is required to eliminate active systemic disease.

 

  • Some conditions it is seen associated with: Rheumatoid arthritis, Polyarteritis Nodosa, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Crohn’s disease.
  • Scleritis is usually a bilateral disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Common in Males- Scleritis occurs most frequently in women.

 

Option D. Only superficial infiltration noted - Dense lymphocytic infiltration deep within the sclera tissue is present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pain is a prominent feature of scleritis.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 226

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented with acute onset redness in right eye. It was not associated with pain or discharge. History of previous similar episodes noted. The clinical presentation is given below. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nodular Episcleritis

 

Option C:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: Asymptomatic elastotic degeneration of the conjunctival stroma. A yellow–white mound or aggregation of smaller mounds is seen on the bulbar conjunctiva adjacent to the limbus.

 

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Simple granulomas are common following squint surgery, as foreign body granuloma and following inadequately scraped chalazion. They consist of an extensive polypoid, cauliflower-like growth of granulation tissue.

 

 

Option D. Scleritis: It is inflammation of sclera leading to severe pain and redness of the eye. It is associated with collagen vascular disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumscribed nodule of dense leucocytic infiltration is suggestive of episcleritis.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 225

choices.text: Behind the insertion of rectus muscles

questions.text: Which is the thinnest part of the sclera?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Behind the insertion of rectus muscles

 

Option C:

 

  • Sclera is a tough, opaque outer covering of the eyeball (5/6th)
  • Origin is from Neural crest

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Around the Optic Nerve: The sclera thickness is 1mm.

 

Option B. At the Equator: Sclera is not the thinnest at the equator.

 

Option D. At the limbus: The scleral thickness is 0.83mm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Thinnest part of the sclera is behind the insertion of the rectus muscles.

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 225

questions.text: An elderly woman with the following ocular finding came to the OPD. She is most likely having which of the following systemic conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

 

Option D:

 

  • The picture given is of Necrotizing scleritis without inflammation aka SCLEROMALACIA PERFORANS.
  • It is seen in patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis.
  • There is painless scleral thinning with melting in severe cases.
  • The underlying cause is believed to be ischaemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.

 

Option B. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and eyes.

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy that primarily affects the muscles and skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is most commonly seen in patients with Rheumatoid arthritis

 

 

Ref: PARSON’S DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 228

questions.text: â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹A middle-aged woman presents with dull, ocular pain, mild proptosis and decreased vision. Ultrasonography was performed, and the provided image shows characteristic “T Sign”. Based on these clinical manifestations and imaging, what is the most probable aetiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior Scleritis

 

Option A:

 

  • The given picture is of a B-scan sonogram showing T sign which is characteristic of posterior scleritis. The stem of the T being formed by the optic nerve and the cross bar by the fluid-containing gap.
  • Posterior scleritis is inflammation of sclera behind the equator
  • Ultrasonography shows increased scleral thickness and fluid in the Sub-Tenon space.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Retrobulbar hemorrhage is the accumulation of blood behind the eyeball. It can cause proptosis (bulging of the eye), but it typically does not result in a "T sign" on ultrasonography.

 

Option C. Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the tissues within the orbit. Imaging studies may reveal signs of inflammation, such as fluid accumulation or abscess formation, but it does not typically manifest as a "T sign" on ultrasound.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve. It may present with “double optic nerve” sign on ultrasound to thickening of the perineural sheath,

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "T sign" on ultrasonography is a characteristic finding seen in Posterior scleritis.

 

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION PAGE 298

questions.text: Which of the following scleral layer blends with uveal tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lamina Fusca

 

Option B:

 

  • The inner layer of the sclera (lamina fusca) blends with the uveal tract.
  • Lamina fusca is the innermost layer of sclera.
  • It blends with the suprachoroidal and supraciliary lamina of uveal tract.
  • Brownish in color due to presence of pigmented cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The supraciliary lamina is a thin, fibrous layer that lies between the sclera and the ciliary body. It blends with the uveal tract, specifically the ciliary body.

 

Option C. The basal lamina is a layer of extracellular matrix found throughout the body, including in the eye.

 

Option D. Lamina cribrosa is a part of sclera which is sieve-like through which optic nerve fibres pass. Also, it is located at the back of the eye, near the optic nerve head. It is not directly associated with blending into the uveal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The scleral layer that blends with the uveal tract is Lamina fusca.

 

 

Ref: COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY KHURANA PAGE 136

questions.text: Which of the following passes through the middle aperture of sclera?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vortex Veins

 

Option B:

 

These are four to six large veins that drain the uvea of the eye and exit through the sclera.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Long Ciliary Nerve: These nerves are branches of the nasociliary nerve, a part of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. They typically pass through the sclera around the optic nerve, not through the middle aperture.

 

Option C. Anterior Ciliary Nerve: These nerves are associated with the extraocular muscles and supply the anterior segment of the eye.

 

Option D. Posterior Ciliary Artery: The posterior ciliary arteries, branches of the ophthalmic artery, supply the choroid, ciliary body, iris, and optic nerve head. These arteries penetrate the sclera around the optic nerve, through the posterior part, not the middle aperture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vortex veins pass through the middle aperture of the sclera.

 

 

Ref: COMPREHENSIVE OPHTHALMOLOGY KHURANA PAGE 135
